```{python}
#| execution: {iopub.execute_input: '2024-03-05T11:34:27.277710Z', iopub.status.busy: '2024-03-05T11:34:27.277388Z', iopub.status.idle: '2024-03-05T11:34:28.062241Z', shell.execute_reply: '2024-03-05T11:34:28.061606Z'}

from plotnine import (
    ggplot,
    aes,
    geom_point,
    scale_shape_manual,
)
from plotnine.data import mtcars
```

You can create shape symbols using $\TeX$. For example

```{python}
#| execution: {iopub.execute_input: '2024-03-05T11:34:28.065324Z', iopub.status.busy: '2024-03-05T11:34:28.064959Z', iopub.status.idle: '2024-03-05T11:34:29.425365Z', shell.execute_reply: '2024-03-05T11:34:29.424582Z'}
#| scrolled: false
mixed_shapes = (
    r"$\mathrm{A}$",
    r"$\mathrm{B}$",
    r"$\mathrm{C}$",
    r"$\mathrm{D}$",
)


(
    ggplot(mtcars, aes("wt", "mpg", shape="factor(gear)", colour="factor(gear)"))
    + geom_point(size=6)
    + scale_shape_manual(values=mixed_shapes)
)
```



See matplotlib [documentation](https://matplotlib.org/users/mathtext.html) for more.
